segments.text: convenient at that time you were saying?

Reserve units were sort of few and far between and they had not been re-established and there were no armories really and the program was really in the grassroots and there were some geographical divisions in other words if you lived in one county you had to go a certain direction to
to meet there were, I think they called them reserve areas or some such thing.
I lived in Hearn, and the closest place that I could find to participate in the reserve was in Temple, which was 65 miles away.
So there were four of us that pulled our automobile and started driving back and forth to Temple.
And I think we met twice a month there, not
on a real regular scale, no pay, just met for points and comradeship and just to keep in on the know.
We'd have speakers that had come that were Army people, and we'd have people that knew of the development in the military.
It really was not a real organized type outfit.
And there was every branch in the world in it.
Oh, really?
They called it a composite regiment.
You just came, and somebody was designated the commander, and he probably got a few little administrative pays, but we got on the points.
Well, what'd you do in it?
And this is from 1946 to 1951 then?
That's right.
And what was your duty there?
We'd be assigned to...
come up with a program for the whole group.
Maybe mine might be on building a highway bridge or something along my line.
And then we studied, we took advantage of a lot of the correspondence courses that the Army had.
And we utilized those to just enhance our knowledge and whatnot.
But it really was not
Not really what you'd call anything real constructive branch-wise.
It really was just a sort of a holding unit, just to keep people together.
And we did have the opportunity to go to summer camp a couple of times.
Did you get paid for that?
Yes, we did.
We were on active duty then.
I mean, just like any other two weeks.
But you didn't go two weeks every summer because it was so disorganized.
You just went a couple of times in those five years.
I think I only went two times.
Then I think I went one time as a casual.
I just got an opportunity to be called and went up to Fort Hood and served with an engineer battalion.
So I may have gone three times, but two or three, it was not anything regular like it is now.
All this time, you were part of the reserve unit attached to the Corps of Engineers, right?
I was a Corps of Engineer officer.
Okay.
But we were under what was called Texas Military District, which headquartered in Austin, and they administered all the reserves.
It didn't matter whether you were engineer, artillery, infantry.
It was sort of a control headquarters.
But it's called Texas Military District.
Okay.
They maintained records.
Right.
Now, as an engineering officer, what relation did you have, or what relationship did you have, your reserve unit have, with the Corps of Engineers who built Somerville Dam?
None.
None?
Not at that time.
Ever?
Did you ever?
We did after we got in this engineer brigade, yes.
And when did you erect the engineering brigade?
I got into it in 51 or 52, I guess.
51 through 65, okay.
Right, okay.
Okay.
That's when they finally broke down these county lines and allowed me to come from Roberson County to Brazos County and let me join this 420th Engineer Brigade.
Right.
And that's what I'd been wanting to do for, well, it had been in being for a couple of years.
But why did they erect the 420th?

Spencer Buchanan, who is a consultant here, envisioned the opportunity to come up with an engineer unit and utilize a lot of engineer reserve officers to start building the reserve program in this area.
And he got them together and got the designation and started the unit.
It was his doings, basically, just in order to promote the reserve program.
And the Army Reserve went along with this.
Oh, yeah.
I think by that time, they were probably beginning to...

have funds and uh places and Korean war just yeah right around the corner and it it started as a I believe as an engineer group or battalion battalion or group and subsequently got designated as a brigade so he commanded it for its initial birth and infancy and kicked it off the ground and
Most of the officers in it were engineer officers.
And he built a good program and started it very constructively.
And I went with it the first time I went to summer camp was in 1952.
They did not go, I believe, prior to my going as a group, as a brigade.
So the first time it went to summer camp was 1952.
We went up to Mineral Wells, up to Walters Air Force Base, and we built roads and little landing strips and oil tank pads and, you know, the gamut.
He was a stickler for getting up there and building something that you could see and use.
He was sort of oriented toward the Air Force.
In fact, we were at one time called Air Force Engineer Brigade.
So it was sort of designated toward the Air Force.
But we began to do things that were
were constructive and instructive, and it grew in a pretty good hurry.
It blossomed.
Okay, now let's get back to that question.
What relations do they have with the Corps of Engineers since the early 1950s?
Okay, we would work, we would go to summer camp, and a lot of the work we did was with the civilian Corps of Engineers at a
Class I installation, like Walters Air Force Base has a, their engineer was called a director of installations or some such thing, but he was part of the engineering aspect of that installation.
And he'd have certain chores that he was going to do with his own forces or contract it, and we'd use our engineer people, and he'd furnish materials.

Subsequent to that, we did some jobs as time went along with the actual Corps of Engineers, things that they had that they were going to have done and pay for, and we'd do it in coordination with them to utilize.
You'd do it on like a summer camp basis?
That's right.
That's right.
What kind of projects?
I mean, like did you work out at Somerville or did you?
No, we never did work at Somerville, but we worked at,
Oh, we worked at Fort Sill, Oklahoma, Fort Chaffee, Arkansas, Fort Polk, Louisiana, Bullis, Camp Bullis, Fort Sam Houston, Fort Bliss.
up at Red River Arsenal in Texarkana.
Anywhere there was an installation that we could go and do work that was constructive to us, we were very insistent that we not make work type things.
Build something that they were going to tear down.
Sure, right.
You can really tear a man's morale up to have him go out and labor and sweat and build something
that he knows is going to serve no purpose whatsoever.

And one of the prime concerns that I had as a brigade commander was, if at all possible, never build anything that's going to be torn up unless it was made to be torn up, something to be able to explode or blow up or something like that.
We always wanted to build something that was going to be
utilized or have some utility.

We, the Corps of Engineers, I'm talking about reserve units or engineer units, in my opinion had a head and shoulders start on a lot of the other type of military organizations, infantry per se, artillery, the other people because
we could teach people skills that they could use to make a living at.
Now, an infantryman, he's a very important part of the war, but you can take an infantryman out and nothing that he learns at summer camp can he make a nickel with.
But we taught bulldozer operators, motor grader operators, crane operators, welders, divers.
You know, just

thousands of skills and many of those people got civilian jobs on the strength of learning it in the reserve program and it was real easy back in the times when it was hard to get people enlisting in reserve units we didn't have much trouble because we had a program that could pay them dollars and cents and it just made a big difference
I had never thought of that aspect of it.
And you could tell a man when he came out to recruit him that he could teach him skills that he could make a living with.
Pretty interesting to him.
How many reserve engineering brigades are there in Texas?
Just one.
That's what I thought.
There are four in the United States.
Oh, that's all.
That's fascinating.
Where are the other three?
Well, there was one.
Now, there were four.
Now, two of them have subsequent.
There were four when?
Well, when I was in the reserve.
Okay.
Okay.
There were four, but two of them have been re-designated as engineer commands, they call it, and they're commanded by a two-star general.
And we were not fortunate enough to get one of those.
Why do they need a two-star general?
Why were they re-designated?
I'm not real sure.
The concept of it was that they were going to give them broader responsibilities
in the event of emergencies, and they were going to handle a broader area of engineer responsibilities, less of a direct responsibility like we had of actually commanding the units.
They would have an umbrella type responsibility, like there was one in Vietnam that
that was responsible to the theater commander for all engineer activities in Vietnam.
And it's just a bigger responsibility.
So they re-designated two of them as engineer commands and then left two of them as engineer brigades.
Now, there's one in Chicago, one in New York, one in Vicksburg, and one in Brown, Texas, Vicksburg, Mississippi.
Why Vicksburg?
The Waterways Experiment Station.
Now, that was one that was designated as a command, and the one in Chicago was designated as a command.
Now, the one in Vicksburg, and I think the reason it was activated in the first place was they've got a big waterway experiment station over there,
belongs to the Corps of Engineers, and they've got lots of Corps of Engineer officers there.
And I'm sure that's the reason it was originally organized like this one was here.
But why the two were chosen for two stars, I think it was politics, Senator Strom Thurmond
Mississippi, or wherever you want to know that.
Who was from Mississippi?
Anyhow, one of the big armed forces man was... Eastman, isn't he?
I don't remember, but anyhow, we always thought that there was a lot of politics in it, because we thought we had about as good a run as anybody.
Well, that's something, though.
There's four of them in the country, and we're one of them.
There's one in Germany, and...
It's under Seventh Army.
And then there was one in Vietnam.
But that's on active duty, yeah.
That's correct.
But full reserve.
Yeah, that was a compliment to Brian to have one, and just four in the States.
Certainly does seem like it to me.
OK, let's talk a little bit about your career.
In December of 1946, you were promoted to major.
Then your next promotion didn't come for 14 years until 1960.
Why is that?
Well, there just was not an opening.
We had a pretty static outfit.
People got in and they didn't get out much.
But it just was not an opening.
I used to hoorah that I was the oldest major in the United States Army Reserve.
But the opening just didn't occur.
The fellow got in a position where he stayed with it.
So, you know, I just never got the opportunity.
Well, did you ever get frustrated about that?
Oh, not really.
So you never considered getting out of the resource because they didn't promote you?
No, it was a real satisfying job.
I had several jobs during that time, principally the brigade engineer, but the fellow that was above me just stayed and stayed, and so it just didn't come off.
I was under the impression that after you went up for a rank, then you came under review.
Uh, and after you've been reviewed a couple of times, then they might not let you stay in the... That didn't happen in the reserve, or didn't over those years.
It did not happen, no.
That was not part of the, part of the program.
It is now, though, isn't it?
I think that's right.
I think that's correct, and it probably should be.
Uh, in fact, I think now, uh, they limit certain positions to maybe three years or five years or some such thing.
Fortunately for me, they didn't at that time, because I might have dropped out of the program of necessity.
Sure, sure.
In fact, I had to drop out a couple of times, just very temporarily, because when I got promoted to lieutenant colonel, there was no slot for me.
I got the promotion, and then the slot did not...

stay for some circumstance and I had to drop out for six months or some such thing but I stayed I stayed continued with the unit on an unpaid basis just because I was interested in it and and then it opened right back up and I got back in and when I was promoted to a full colonel I think I got out just shortly but
Anyhow, everything worked great.
Well, that's the thing about your career in the reserves.
For 14 years, you're not promoted at all, and then from 1960 to 1966, the matoric rise, this one promotion after another.
How can you account for that?
Well, here again, it's just one of those things where when I got promoted to lieutenant colonel, I got the opportunity to go to command general staff school, which made me eligible for...
on up and very shortly thereafter well the man who was in the full colonel slot well he died so I was moved into that slot and then see I was only a full colonel just two years or two years and
A little over something, a very minimum of time.
Three years.
Okay, just under three, wasn't it?
Mm-hmm.
And at that time then, Cliff Samang, who was my predecessor, had mandatory retirement.
See, a brigade commander did have mandatory.
He had a time limit.
It was either 30 years or five years in grade, whichever came later.
So he had mandatory retirement.
and I moved into his slot.
So, why they used to hoot on me, I said, once I got off that major spot that I really went up.
And it does look funny.
In other words, there wasn't any time in grade?
I mean, you were a lieutenant colonel, um,
just for three years?
There would have been.
Then you were a colonel for less than three years?
That's right.
You didn't have to be a colonel for five years and a lieutenant colonel for four years?
No, I think a full colonel, you had to be a full colonel 30 months, three years.
I was right on top of it.
I was just barely eligible.
Of course, I stayed a colonel
six months after I was assigned to the, as a brigade commander.
Right.
But I was just under the wire.
How many officers did you have in that brigade that were a similar rank?
Similar rank?
Rank, yeah, that were lieutenant colonels or colonels.
Well, let's see.
Only the, well, there was only one colonel in the 420th.
Then there was
There were two groups, and each of them had a full colonel.
There were only three.
And then there were probably five or six lieutenant colonels.
But just three full colonels in the brigade at that time.
Well, why'd they pick you instead of some of the other colonels?
Just thought I was more qualified.
That's what I like to think.
And another thing.
I lived here, and the unit was here, and I'm sure that had something to do with it.
But I know that Cliff Samang recommended me highly, and I know that the higher headquarters take the present brigade commander's recommendations.
I know they're evaluated.
That doesn't mean that they always go along with it, but I do know that he recommended me.
So in the fact that I was an engineer officer, I can't help but think they thought I was the most qualified.
Now, we talked about this for a few minutes after the tape recorder was off yesterday.
And that is that you were appointed district engineer for district 17 of the highway department in the summer of 1966.
And then six months later, you were appointed general.
Was there any relationship there?
Do you think that the fact that you have this new position of responsibility with the highway department might have had some bearing on the fact that you were made a general?
I don't believe so.
The command position called for a brigadier general.
Now, the only question at that time, they had a few

surplus brigadier generals in the reserve program and there was in fact when they called me and told me they were signing me to the 420th this major general said to me this doesn't necessarily mean you're going to get a promotion because they feasibly could assign some other brigadier general to sign this unit to take up that slot in other words he's a surplus
unassigned officer somewhere, and if he wanted that unit, they'd consider assigning him.
So he said, that doesn't necessarily follow that you'll be promoted, but he said, I'm going to recommend you.
So the unit, it just called for a brigadier general.
If I was going to command the unit continuously, then they almost had to promote me.
But within that six months time, they could have brought somebody else in and relieved me and
and given him the unit, not one to be promoted, I don't think, but if they had had a surplus brigadier general, they could have done that.

Now, did you really tell what you were telling me yesterday about how one day you got a phone call and the next day... Well, I had been interviewed by my boss in the highway department for possibly assigning me as a district engineer for the highway department, and
The districts, the highway department is divided in 25 districts.
That's a very prestigious job in the highway department.
That's lots of responsibility and lots of latitude.
Works with broad guidelines.
And he had interviewed me and he called me and I'm not certain whether, he called me one day and the army man called me the next, but
On a Tuesday, I was called by one of them and said he was assigning me as District Engineer of the Highway Department.
I was called the next day, almost the same time of day, just before noon, that I had been assigned as the commanding officer of the 420th Engineer Brigade, which called for Brigadier General.
So two days in a row, I got very prestigious assignments.
The greatest two years of your life.
Two days.
That's right.
Somebody said that was my blue ribbon week, and it was.
It led to great things for me.
I had a marvelous career, both civilian-wise and Army.
I was at the right place a lot of times.
I had some excellent recommendations apparently and got moved in some slots that were most rewarding.
Now let's move back to the Reserves right after the Second World War.
It sounds like they were somewhat in disarray.
That's correct.
They had, of course, not had any chance to regroup after the war.
Yeah.
A world of people that were discharged were sick and tired of war, army.
They went here, thither, and yon.
And it was a matter of gathering some little nucleuses for people to go to responding to and building around.
So it was almost a total rebuilding job.
And that's what sounds like happened from 46 into today, as a matter of fact.
That's right.
Of course, well, I guess starting in, I want to say now about,
middle and latter 50s and early 60s there was a great emphasis put on the reserve program.
Why do you think that was?
Well I guess the result of the Korean War they saw the need for a strong reserve and lots of monies were appropriated and built armories and when you got nice facilities that lends itself.
Of course another thing was the
The fact that we still had the draft, and the draft assisted the reserve program greatly.
Sure.
Erroneously, people referred to reservists as draft dodgers.
And that was completely erroneous.
The reserve was a form of a man fulfilling his requirement.
The draft was another.
Now, it's true, I'm quite sure, that many people knew they would be drafted and got in the reserve because they could stay at home, they could drill on weekends, they could go to summer camps.
But that was the law.
I mean, that was legal.
But a lot of people got called raft dodgers for getting in the reserve.
But I'll tell you for sure, we had waiting lines to get in.
throughout the 1950s.
Oh, yes.
Well, it varied, but it seemed to me like it started in the later 50s and in the 60s.
There were a few times that we had lists, and there were some pretty stringent requirements on who you took in the reserve.
I mean, it wasn't unusual to get a congressional on why you took so-and-so over this person.
What do you mean, get a congressional?
Well, an investigation.
Oh, really?
Congressional investigation.
No kidding?
People would write to the congressman, I wasn't taken in this reserve unit, and I ought to have gotten in, and you know, this type of thing.
No kidding.
Was that more in the 60s or the war in Vietnam?
No, well, I really don't remember the time frame, but it was during the time that the draft was very active and people were...
were utilizing the reserve to fulfill their obligations, and they wanted in.
But it has seesawed.
There'd be times that you can't get them in the reserve.
Then there are times that you've got a waiting list for reserve, and right now they're having trouble again getting them in the reserve.
But the draft played a great part in keeping the reserve program going.
I would think so.
